title: Turn up the heat on energy companies before the Arctic winter arrives
text:
Turn up the heat on energy companies before the Arctic winter arrives Turn up the heat on energy companies before the Arctic winter arrives WITH forecasters warning that Britain is facing an Arctic winter freeze, now is the time to grab a cheaper deal for your heating bills. PUBLISHED: 16:35, Tue, Sep 22, 2015 | UPDATED: 16:51, Tue, Sep 22, 2015 GETTY Don't get to cosy with your energy supplier, it might be time to shop around 
Many have a real incentive to act as an incredible 24 fixed rate tariffs expire this month, instantly pushing up energy bills for most users. 
It is just six weeks until the nation’s big heating “switch on” and new research suggests households can save hundreds of pounds by switching supplier. 
October 31 is the most popular day for households to turn on their heating on a daily basis and comparison site MoneySupermarket.com has calculated that bill payers can save up to £264 a year by switching supplier in advance. Related articles 
Energy expert Stephen Murray explained: “With the cold weather forecast to hit record lows this year it is worth spending time now to find the best value deal before reaching for the thermostat.” 
Murray said the current cheapest tariff available is from GB Energy Supply. 
Its Premium Energy Saver costs on average £831 a year, £264 cheaper than the average tariff of £1,095. 
This is a variable rate tariff so if energy prices rose, so would your charges. Murray added: “If you want greater security, Extra Energy offers the current market leading fixed tariff to December 2016 with an average bill of £844.” With a huge number of fixed tariffs coming to an end this month it is really important to keep on top of when your deal expires Caroline Lloyd energy spokesperson at GoCompare 
Those households on fixed tariffs will see their energy bills leap more than 15 per cent when their dual-fuel gas and electricity rates expire at the end of this month, according to GoCompare.com. 
British Gas, Co-operative Energy, Extra Energy, First:Utility, iSupply, M&S Energy and Scottish Power all have tariffs running that are due to expire on September 30. 
Customers will pay an extra £151 on average when they automatically roll over onto their supplier’s standard variable tariff. 
Households on Extra Energy’s ValuePlus Fixed Price Sept 2015 v1 tariff face a hike of nearly 20 per cent, costing them on average £186. 
And First:Utility customers on the expiring iSave Fixed v27 September 2015 in the Norweb distribution area, which includes Manchester, face rises of 25 per cent costing them almost £313 on average. 
Caroline Lloyd , energy spokesperson at GoCompare.com said: “With a huge number of fixed tariffs coming to an end this month it is really important to keep on top of when your deal expires.” 
Households who stay loyal to their energy provider typically end up on a more expensive tariff, Lloyd said. 
“With potential average savings of £300, it pays to spend a few minutes comparing tariffs to see what you can save,” she added. 
Disillusioned households are increasingly shunning Big Six suppliers British Gas, E.On, Npower, EDF Energy, Scottish Power and SSE. 
Independent suppliers such as Extra Energy, Flow Energy, Ovo Energy, and First:Utility, as well as green suppliers Good Energy and Ecotricity, offer competitive tariffs and also score highly when it comes to ratings in customer satisfaction. 
There are 1 9 independents with nearly 10 per cent of the dual-fuel market, led by First:Utility, which has a 4 per cent share and 765,000 households, according to new research from Cornwall Energy. 
The Big Six are finally feeling the heat after years of overcharging so don’t be afraid to give them the cold shoulder. Related articles
